newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asian crudes edge back, Oman trades, Tapis rises.
newsitem.headline: Asian crudes edge back, Oman trades, Tapis rises.

text.p: Crude oil prices in Asia were slightly weaker on Friday with a few more cargos of Oman being mopped up, although the Tapis premium climbed further.
Traders said they added a further three Oman sales to their tally for November trading but at prices no higher than MPM plus one cent.
They said a Chinese state trader sold one cargo to a Thai refinery at MPM flat and a second to a Singapore refiner at half a cent premium to MPM.
A third Oman was was traded between majors at MPM plus one cent, they said.
Traders estimated that two or three cargos of Oman were still left on the November shelf -- lagging other Gulf grades which are mostly sold with the exception of a Lower Zakum and possibly a Murban.
A 300,000 barrel cargo of early November Tapis was sold fob to a Japanese trader for supplying into Burma on a delivered basis.

The premium reached $1.40, surpassing the previous November deal into Korea by 20 cents. But traders said the price alone was not necessarily a strong indication of the price because of the risk premium being associated with trading into Burma.
Taiwan decided not to opt out of its term contract purchases for West African grades from Elf, despite the wide Brent/Dubai.
CPC will take two November VLCCs, shared three parts Forcados, one part Angolan Palance in one, and three Forcados and one Odudu in the second, traders said.
Paper Tapis also retreated. November was assessed at $24.20/$24.50, down 15 cents. A Wall Street trader and a trader exchanged December paper at $23.85.
Traders said Minas has traded as high as a premium of 24 cents above the ICP after China bought 500,000 barrels from two equity producers between 21 and 24 cents over.
